thread.title: Tourists continue to dice with death on crumbling white cliffs
thread.title_full: Tourists continue to dice with death on crumbling white cliffs

author: eTN Global Editor
title: Tourists continue to dice with death on crumbling white cliffs
text:
Tourists continue to dice with death on crumbling white cliffs Adv: two German girls take snapshots on the Seven Sisters cliffs at Cuckmere Haven, East Sussex Adv: 
SEAFORD, England - It's just days since the son of singer Nick Cave tragically died falling from a cliff nearby, and a group of youngsters were lambasted for sitting with their legs dangling over a 300ft precipice. 
But on the ever-crumbling white cliffs of the South Coast, daytrippers continue to dice with death by posing for the ultimate photograph. 
It was at Haven Brow, the first of the Seven Sisters, that the party of teenagers were pictured with their legs hanging over the edge last week. 
And Arthur Cave, 15, fell from a cliff at Ovingdean Gap, on the outskirts of Brighton, last Tuesday. Ninety minutes before the tragedy, the public school pupil, who lived with his parents and twin brother, Earl, in the family’s £2.5million home in Brighton, had sent a smiling selfie of himself standing a few yards away from where he fell. 
An onlooker said: ‘The cliff at this spot has no fence. Most British people you see there keep about 30ft back. But foreign visitors — parties from schools or English language colleges, or Japanese tourists — apparently aren’t aware the cliffs can crumble. 
‘Some go to within a foot of the edge, not knowing they are standing on an overhang that could break away at any moment — and they are there all for the sake of a selfie.’
